title: VC Daily: Logistics-Tech Deals Continue as Choppy Waters Approach
text:
Chicago-based freight booking and pricing startup Loadsmart Inc., said last week that it raised a $200 million round of Series D financing led by SoftBank Latin America Fund, part of the SoftBank Group, with participation from investors including funds and accounts managed by BlackRock, rail-based freight company CSX Corp. and asset manager Janus Henderson Group. Loadsmart's software aims to help shippers, warehouses and carriers move freight more efficiently.

Meanwhile, Seattle-based Logixboard, which focuses on freight forwarding software and is aiming to offer logistics providers a payment-processing system, last month said it raised a $32 million Series B round from Insight Partners and investors including Redpoint Ventures and F-Prime Capital.

The logistics tech funding environment has surely been boosted by the current global supply-chain crunch. But its ability to stay robust remains to be seen as the venture industry begins to feel the effects of lackluster public markets.

And now on to the news...

Advertisement

Top News

Dive's battery-powered torpedo-shaped vessels are 19 feet long and can be used for defense and commercial missions. PHOTO: DIVE TECHNOLOGIES

Drone M&A. Anduril Industries Inc., a startup that develops drones with military and commercial applications, has acquired Dive Technologies, another startup that builds unmanned submarines, WSJ Pro's Marc Vartabedian reports.

The deal, whose value wasn't disclosed, expands Anduril's product range as the company ramps up national-security work with the U.S. Defense Department.

The acquisition, announced Wednesday, comes as startups are playing a larger role in the industry's partnership with the U.S. military. The Defense Department has increasingly turned to startups to bolster its technological prowess in recent years. Young companies including drone defense startup Fortem Technologies Inc. and autonomous piloting company Shield AI have signed military contracts.

Boston-based Dive's torpedo-shaped vessels are 19 feet long and can be used for defense and commercial missions including oceanographic sensing, anti-submarine warfare, seabed mapping and oil-pipeline inspections. The battery-powered vessels can go as deep as 6,000 meters (about 19,700 feet) and stay out on missions for weeks, the company said.

$31 Billion

Drop in Mark Zuckerberg's net worth on Thursday.

Trialjectory Collects $20 Million to Match Cancer Patients to Trials

Trialjectory Inc., a startup led by a cancer survivor, has raised $20 million in new venture capital to expand a service that uses artificial intelligence to match cancer patients with clinical trials, WSJ Pro's Brian Gormley reports. Trialjectory, which previously raised $7.7 million in seed financing, secured this Series A round of funding from Insight Partners, which led the financing, plus new investor JAL Ventures and return backers Contour Venture Partners, Rho Capital Partners and TIA Ventures.

Louisiana Teachers' Pension Preps Venture Portfolio Secondary Sale

Teachers' Retirement System of Louisiana is considering a possible sale of up to $300 million of certain venture-capital funds in the secondary market, WSJ Pro's Preeti Singh reports, citing pension documents. Funds the state pension aims to sell are part of a venture fund portfolio built and managed by its investment adviser, Hamilton Lane, through an account the firm manages exclusively for the pension, according to a document prepared for a pension overseers meeting.

Industry News

Funds

London-based SuperSeed has closed on £31 million (about $42 million) in commitments toward its second fund, which has a target of £50 million. The new fund will invest between £500,000 and £1.5 million in 30-35 U.K. startups focusing on business and industrial automation.

New York-based Noemis Ventures launched with a $25 million debut fund focusing on fintech, AI/machine learning and marketplaces.

People

Proton.ai, an artificial intelligence-powered sales platform for distributors, hired Kevin Colón as chief revenue officer. He was previously at Salesloft. Proton.ai recently secured a $20 million Series A round led by Felicis Ventures.

Business-software company dbt Labs Inc. appointed Margaret Francis to the post of chief product officer. She was previously president and chief operating officer at Armory. In June, dbt Labs said it raised a $150 million Series C round co-led by Altimeter Capital Management, Sequoia Capital and Andreessen Horowitz.

Exits

Cybersecurity company Forescout Technologies Inc., which is backed by private-equity firms Advent International and Crosspoint Capital Partners, acquired healthcare cybersecurity provider CyberMDX for an undisclosed amount. CyberMDX previously raised funding from investors including Pitango Venture Capital and Qure Ventures.

Advertisement

New Money

Global logistics platform Flexport on Monday said it raised $935 million in a Series E investment round that brings its post-money valuation to more than $8 billion. Venture-capital giant Andreessen Horowitz and billionaire Michael Dell's MSD Partners led the round, which also included an investment from Shopify Inc., a Canadian online platform for retailers.

Platform Science Inc., a San Diego-based technology platform for commercial vehicles, scored $115 million in Series C funding. SoftBank Vision Fund 2 led the round, which included additional support from Chimera, 8VC and others. David Boriss, director at SoftBank Investment Advisers, will join the company's board.

Qredo, a London-based digital asset management infrastructure and product suite, secured $80 million in Series A funding, bringing the company's valuation to $460 million. 10T Holdings led the round, which included participation from Coinbase Ventures, Avalanche, Terra, Kingsway Capital, HOF Capital, Raptor Group and GoldenTree Asset Management.

Channable, an e-commerce feed management and pay-per-click automation provider based in the Netherlands, snagged more than $62 million in Series B financing. Led by Partech, the investment included participation from Peak.

Tribal, a business-to-business payments and financing platform for small and medium-sized businesses in emerging markets, nabbed $60 million in Series B funding. SoftBank Latin America Fund led the investment, which included support from Coinbase Ventures, BECO Capital, QED Investors and Rising Tide Fund.

Celestial AI, a Santa Clara, Calif.-based artificial intelligence computing startup, raised $56 million in Series A funding. Koch Disruptive Technologies led the round, with Managing Director Isaac Sigron joining the board. Temasek's Xora Innovation fund, The Engine, Tyche Partners, M-Ventures, IMEC XPand and Fitz Gate Ventures also participated in the round.

Torii, a New York-based automated software-as-a-service management platform, grabbed $50 million in Series B financing. Tiger Global Management led the round, which included support from Wing Venture Capital, Global Founders Capital, Uncork Capital, Entree Capital and Scopus Ventures.

Koneksa, a New York-based digital biomarker platform, completed a $45 million Series C round led by AyurMaya, an affiliated fund of Matrix Capital Management. Additional investors included Takeda Ventures, Velosity Capital, McKesson Ventures, Merck Global Health Innovation Fund, dRx Capital, Spring Mountain Capital and Waterline Ventures. Along with the funding round, Koneksa appointed John A. Wagner as the company's first chief medical officer. He was previously CMO at Cygnal Therapeutics. Karan Takhar, senior managing director at Matrix, will join Koneksa's board.

Mos, a San Francisco-based startup offering banking and scholarship access services to students, raised $40 million in Series B funding at a $400 million valuation. Lead investor Tiger Global Management was joined by Sequoia Capital, Lux Capital and others in the round.

Novi Connect, a San Francisco-based business-to-business marketplace for sustainable ingredients and packaging, picked up a $40 million investment. Tiger Global Management led the funding, which included follow-on investments from Defy.vc and Greylock Partners.

Melonn, which provides end-to-end fulfillment and software services to small and medium-sized e-commerce companies in Latin America, closed a $20 million Series A round. QED Investors led the investment, which saw participation from Global Founders Capital, Alter Global, NFX, Pear, Wollef and others.

Flexio, a Mexico City-based business-to-business payments startup serving Latin America, landed a $3 million seed investment led by Costanoa Ventures.

Pay Theory Inc., a Cincinnati-based payments startup, was seeded with a $2 million investment led by Zeal Capital Partners.
